Comment: Not exactly how Medicaid works, but I get your sentiment.  The Medicaid application process varies from state to state as the program is managed at the state level.  However, there is no such thing as "a week of benefits."  You either meet the qualifications in your state or you don't.  Benefits are typically reevaluated every 12 months.  Instituting work requirements will do several things:  1. Require states to institute a mechinism for beneficiaries to report their employment status and likely hours worked.  This will create additional administrative overhead likely costing more than any reduction in beneficiaries would save.  2. By default eliminate caregivers and others who can not work for one reason or another.  Including people who may or will qualify for disability, but are still working their way through what is often a multi-year process to apply for Social Security Disability benefits.  These people may not survive without care while waiting for a disability determination.  3. Cause people who would otherwise be eligible for benefits to be denied or dropped because either due to mental disability, poor language proficiency, or lack of education are unable to properly complete the application and regularly report their work acitivity.  Some may not have regular or reliable Internet access or know how to navigate the Internet and the government system for reporting the information.  These are just the top three issues most often cited for the problem with work requirements.  They are nothing more than a way to cut benefits while using a "bootstraps" argument that resonates with people who still believe in the "welfare queen" myth pushed in the 1980's to attack the social safety net.
